Description: The second (and last) X-rated Best-Picture nominee, Stanley Kubrick's dystopian future appalled some viewers with its ultra-violence.
Title: A Clockwork Orange

Description: This gore-soaked movie‚??s use of ‚??found footage‚?ù to reveal the fate of a missing documentary crew made it seem too real.
Title: Cannibal Holocaust

Description: Pier Paolo Pasolini‚??s politically provocative and sexually explicit movie equates fascism and sexual torture.
Title: SalÚ o le 120 giornate di Sodoma

Description: The sight of 13-year-old Linda Blair vomiting, swearing, and abusing herself with a crucifix horrified moviegoers and critics.

Description: This rape-revenge movie so incensed critics Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel that they tried to have it pulled from theaters.

Description: Variety dubbed this historical epic -- written by Gore Vidal, produced by Bob Guccione, and directed by Tinto Brass -- a ‚??moral holocaust.‚?ù
Title: Caligola

Title: Requiem for a Dream

Description: The movie that ushered in ‚??porno chic,‚?ù Deep Throat sparked precedent-setting court cases that challenged assumptions about obscenity.
Title: Deep Throat

Description: Wes Craven changed Ingmar Bergman‚??s The Virgin Spring into a crude, taboo-breaking shocker.
Title: The Last House on the Left

Description: In this grotesque movie, a mad doctor turns three young victims into a twelve-limbed abomination.
Title: The Human Centipede (First Sequence)

Description: Stanley Kubrick played up the dark humor in Nabokov‚??s novel about a middle-aged man infatuated with a pubescent girl.
Title: Lolita

Description: The fact that it was ‚??banned in 40 countries‚?ù was a selling point for this morbid collection of death scenes, some real and some fake.
Title: Faces of Death

Description: Though its sympathies were with the sideshow performers, this circus drama was criticized for casting real-life ‚??human oddities.‚?ù
Title: Freaks

Description: Walkouts were common during this French thriller, which depicts a vicious and lengthy rape and its aftermath in reverse chronological order.

Description: A couple engages in violent sex and sexual violence after their son‚??s death, but art-house audiences took its provocations in stride.
Title: Antichrist

Description: Even in 1915, D.W. Griffith‚??s Civil War epic caused a stir for its stereotypical depiction of African-Americans.
Title: The Birth of a Nation

Description: Mel Gibson's film was called anti-Semitic and became the highest-grossing independent film ever.
Title: The Passion of the Christ

Description: Cult provocateur John Waters used bizarre, crude, tasteless and sexually grotesque images to challenge cultural mores in his first feature.

Description: David Lynch's look at the violence beneath the facade of small-town eighties America was denounced for images of sexual degradation.

Description: Sam Raimi‚??s debut was virtually guaranteed an "X" rating for blood and gore, but the rape scene was the capper, and it was released unrated.
Title: The Evil Dead

Description: Michael Rooker‚??s intense performance made this take on Henry Lee Lucas‚?? crimes feel unbearably real.
Title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer

Description: The National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures reviled Polanski's dark horror classic for making "perverted use‚?ù of Christian beliefs.
Title: Rosemary's Baby

Description: The only X-rated Best-Picture winner, this gritty movie discomfited some viewers with its frank, non-judgmental depiction of homosexuality.
Title: Midnight Cowboy

Description: Michael Cimino‚??s depiction of friendships tested by the Vietnam War won an Oscar, despite accusations of inaccuracy and racism.
Title: The Deer Hunter

Description: Religious fundamentalists picketed and boycotted Martin Scorsese‚??s film on the life of Christ.
Title: The Last Temptation of Christ

Description: A double rape and its aftermath made Sam Peckinpah‚??s movie about a mild-mannered mathematician driven to violence a hot-button topic.
Title: Straw Dogs

Description: This satire lampooned religious zealotry and thus was labeled blasphemous and sacrilegious.
Title: Life of Brian

Description: One of the most influential movies of the seventies was accused of glamorizing Depression-era robbers Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow.

Description: Subtle performances helped make this thriller about a teen sparring with a suspected pedophile seem thought-provoking rather than sleazy.

Title: Brokeback Mountain

Description: Howard Hawk's classic was banned in several states despite pre-release changes designed to counter claims that it glorified gangsters.
Title: Scarface: The Shame of the Nation

Description: David Cronenberg's adaptation of J.G. Ballard‚??s outre novel about people who get off on car crashes was too fetishistic for many.

Description: Is Harry Callahan's contempt for modern criminal-justice protocols a liberal critique of vigilantism or reactionary propaganda?
Title: Dirty Harry

Description: Lolita could still shock 35 years after Kubrick‚??s adaptation; even after extensive cuts, Adrian Lyne‚??s franker version was too hot for theaters.
Title: Lolita

Description: Necrophilia may be the last taboo, and this German gross-out pulled no punches, which is why it was loathed and banned in many markets.

Description: Louis Malle's decision to cast 12-year-old Brooke Shields as a New Orleans prostitute struck many as child exploitation.

Description: Sharon Stone's turn as a seductive bisexual murderess made her a star, but the movie raised hackles for its depiction of lethal lesbians.

Description: Bernardo Bertolucci's NC-17-rated chronicle of sexual discovery hints at incest and other taboos while deliberately evoking erotic art movies of the 60s.

Description: Ken Russell's drama about womanizing priests, sex-crazed nuns, and hysteria in seventeenth-century France was banned in deeply Catholic Italy.
Title: The Devils

Description: Kevin Smith's inquiry into the nature of good and evil is surprisingly sincere, but its vulgar snarkiness still rankled religious leaders.

Description: This Oscar-winning antiwar movie drew fire for portraying young German soldiers with sympathy.

Description: This drama of young bohemians in post 9/11 New York was the most sexually-graphic American movie ever released in non-porn theaters.

Description: Unsimulated sex scenes sparked accusations that filmmaker Larry Clark exploited his teenaged cast, and it was barely distributed in the US.

Description: British critics called Michael Powell's thriller about a tormented murderer perverted, necrophilic, and trashy; his career never recovered.

Description: Inspired by grotesque medical experiments carried out by Japan's notorious Unit 731 during WWII.
Title: Hei tai yang 731

Description: Nagisa Oshima's graphic examination of sexual obsession was seized and edited by US Customs.
Title: Ai no korÓda

Description: Leni Rienfenstahl‚??s gorgeous documentary glorified the Nazis' ideals and iconography.
Title: Triumph des Willens

Description: Peter Greenaway put a high-style gloss on base depravity in this cruel allegory about capitalism.
Title: The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover

Description: Critics worried that Spike Lee's evocation of poverty, police brutality, and racial tensions in Brooklyn would incite violence.

Description: Michael Moore's scathing documentary about George W. Bush's war on terror was a hit despite conservative claims that it was propaganda.

Description: Peter Bogdanovich's melancholy look at adultery, alcoholism, and promiscuity in fifties Texas divided moviegoers and critics.

Description: Critics loved it, but media mogul W.R. Hearst -- the inspiration for Kane - used his influence to discredit Orson Welles' groundbreaking movie.

Description: William Friedkin's sexually frank thriller offended gay-rights activists by implying that homosexuality inevitably leads to murder.

Description: The Catholic Legion of Decency condemned Tennessee Williams' lurid tale of a thumb-sucking child bride and the men who lust for her.

Description: The deaths of actor Vic Morrow and two children while filming prompted new safety regulations.
Title: Twilight Zone: The Movie
Directors: George Miller, Joe Dante, John Landis, Steven Spielberg

Description:
Bloodsucking Freaks (1976)
Women Against Pornography unwittingly raised this ugly horror movie‚??s profile by denouncing its relentless, misogynistic violence.
Title: The Incredible Torture Show

Description: Luis Bunuel's surreal masterpiece was widely condemned for its suggestions of incest, rape and necrophilia.
Title: Viridiana

Description: Tacking a cynical ‚??real‚?ù murder sequence onto a ho-hum exploitation movie generated enough media outrage to make Snuff a lucrative hit.
Title: Snuff

Description: Moviegoers expecting to be titillated were taken aback by this drama's raw, taboo-breaking examination of misogyny.

Description: Outcry over a rape scene involving an Elvis-loving pre-teen (played by 12-year-old Dakota Fanning) helped sink this drama set in 1950s Alabama.

Description: Madonna and Kim Basinger bailed on Jennifer Lynch's story of a sexually troubled surgeon who tames his dream girl by amputation.

Description: Melvin Van Peebles' indie movie reflected the simmering rage of disillusioned African-Americans.
Title: Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song

Description: French filmmaker Catherine Breillat's film on explicit evocation of disturbing desires
Title: Une vraie jeune fille

Description: Americans were shocked by the nudity and sexual frankness of this Czech drama about an unhappy wife searching for fulfillment.

Description: This Italian shockumentary was castigated for exploiting footage of lurid cultural practices from around the world.

Directors: Paolo Cavara, Franco Prosperi, Gualtiero Jacopetti

Description: Mockumentary about ‚ 60s youth was condemned as pornographic.
Title: Jag ‰r nyfiken - en film i gult

Description: The first major studio release rated NC-17, this arty biopic featured a guilt-free menage a trois, nudity and Uma Thurman in a lesbian kiss.
Title: Henry & June

Description: Conservative Christian groups fumed and urged boycotts, but the popularity of Dan Brown's thriller about arcane secrets and occult mysteries won out.
Title: The Da Vinci Code

Description: Bad pre-release buzz, including explosive accusations of animal abuse, helped turn Michael Cimono‚??s epic western into a legendary flop.

Description: When Broadway sensations May Irwin and John Rice's notorious lip-lock was immortalized on film, people were shocked!
Title: The Kiss

Description: Condemnation by the Catholic Church helped make this drama about unchaste priests a hit in Mexico.

Title: September Dawn

Description: Disney's animated musical included lyrics that the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee claimed perpetuated racist stereotypes.

Genres: Animation, Adventure, Comedy, Family, Fantasy, Musical, Romance
